docs.text: MkApi Documentation MkApi is a MkDocs plugin for auto API documentation. MkApi supports the Google Python Style Guide partially. Features of MkApi are: Supported sections: Args , Arguments , Attributes , Example(s) , Note(s) , Raises , Returns , References , Todo , Warning(s) , Warns , Yields . Type annotation. If you write your function such as def func(x: int) -> str: , you don't need write type(s) in Args , Returns , or Yields section. You can overwrite them in your docstring. Automatic type detection. MkApi can create CLASS , DATACLASS , FUNCTION , GENERATOR , METHOD , or PROPERTY prefix for each object. Installation Install the plugin using pip: pip install mkapi MkDocs setting Add the following lines to your mkdocs.yml : plugins: - search - mkapi Note If you have no plugins entry in your config file yet, you'll likely also want to add the search plugin. MkDocs enables it by default if there is no plugins entry set. MkApi usage In your Markdown file, write a embedding of an package, module, function, or other object, just like normal Markdown's image embedding: ![mkapi](<object.qualname>) MkApi imports objects that you specify. If they aren't in sys.path , configure mkdocs.yml like below: plugins: - search - mkapi: src_dirs: [<path_1>, <path_2>, ...] Here, path_X s are inserted to sys.path . path_X s are relative paths from the directory in which mkdocs.yml exists.
docs.title: MkApi

docs.text: MkApi is a MkDocs plugin for auto API documentation. MkApi supports the Google Python Style Guide partially. Features of MkApi are: Supported sections: Args , Arguments , Attributes , Example(s) , Note(s) , Raises , Returns , References , Todo , Warning(s) , Warns , Yields . Type annotation. If you write your function such as def func(x: int) -> str: , you don't need write type(s) in Args , Returns , or Yields section. You can overwrite them in your docstring. Automatic type detection. MkApi can create CLASS , DATACLASS , FUNCTION , GENERATOR , METHOD , or PROPERTY prefix for each object.
docs.title: MkApi Documentation

docs.text: Install the plugin using pip: pip install mkapi
docs.title: Installation

docs.text: Add the following lines to your mkdocs.yml : plugins: - search - mkapi Note If you have no plugins entry in your config file yet, you'll likely also want to add the search plugin. MkDocs enables it by default if there is no plugins entry set.
docs.title: MkDocs setting

docs.text: In your Markdown file, write a embedding of an package, module, function, or other object, just like normal Markdown's image embedding: ![mkapi](<object.qualname>) MkApi imports objects that you specify. If they aren't in sys.path , configure mkdocs.yml like below: plugins: - search - mkapi: src_dirs: [<path_1>, <path_2>, ...] Here, path_X s are inserted to sys.path . path_X s are relative paths from the directory in which mkdocs.yml exists.
docs.title: MkApi usage

docs.text: Examples Let's start realistic examples. Here, sample Python source scripts are stored under the examples directory relative to mkdocs.yml , so you should configure mkdocs.yml like below. In addition, we add two extensions and extra javascript for demonstration. plugins: - search - mkapi: src_dirs: [examples] markdown_extensions: - admonition - pymdownx.arithmatex extra_javascript: - https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/mathjax/2.7.0/MathJax.js?config=TeX-MML-AM_CHTML Function A Python module example.py defines a simple function add . Code 1 example.add def add(x: int, y: int) -> int: """Returns $x + y$. Args: x: The first parameter. y: The second parameter. Returns: Added value. Examples: >>> add(1, 2) 3 !!! note You can use the [admonition extension of MkDocs](https://squidfunk.github.io/mkdocs-material/extensions/admonition/) Note: But you should use `Note` section instead for consistency. """ return x + y Then, you can write an entry to generate API for the function anywhere in your Markdown source: ![mkapi][example.add] MkApi generates the API document for the add function. FUNCTION example.add (x, y) Returns x + y x + y . Parameters x (int) — The first parameter. y (int) — The second parameter. Returns (int) Added value. Examples >>> add(1, 2) 3 Note You can use the admonition extension of MkDocs Note But you should use Note section instead for consistency. Note In the above example, green dashed border is just to show the region of documentation generated by MkApi for convenience. In this simple example, you can see MkApi's features. Auto detection of the type of add (FUNCTION prefix). Type annotation and docstring update for both Parameters and Returns sections. External hyperlink. Use of MkDocs extensions: MathJax rendering and admonition. Generator example.py alse defines a simple generator gen . Code 2 example.gen def gen(n) -> Iterator[str]: """Yields a numbered string. Args: n (int): The length of iteration. Yields: A numbered string """ for x in range(n): yield f"a{x}" Then, ![mkapi][example.gen] creates the API document for the gen generator. GENERATOR example.gen (n) Yields a numbered string. Parameters n (int) — The length of iteration. Yields (str) A numbered string Here, the parameter n has no type annotation but you can specify it in the Args section directly. Class example.py alse defines a simple class ExampleClass . Code 3 example.ExampleClass class ExampleClass: def __init__(self, x: List[int], y: Tuple[str, int]): """A normal class. Args: x: The first parameter. y: The second parameter. Attributes: z (str): The first attribute. Raises: ValueError: If the length of `x` is equal to 0. """ if len(x) == 0: raise ValueError() self.z = "abc" def message(self, n: int) -> str: """A bound method. Args: n: Repeatation Returns: A message """ return self.z * n @property def readonly_property(self): """str: Read-only property documentation.""" return "readonly_property" @property def readwrite_property(self): """list of int: Read-write property documentation.""" return [1, 2, 3] @readwrite_property.setter def readwrite_property(self, value): pass As usual, ![mkapi][example.ExampleClass] creates the API document for the ExampleClass class. CLASS example.ExampleClass (x, y) A normal class. Parameters x (List[int]) — The first parameter. y (Tuple[str, int]) — The second parameter. Attributes z (str) — The first attribute. Raises ValueError — If the length of x is equal to 0. METHOD message (n) A bound method. Parameters n (int) — Repeatation Returns (str) A message READONLY_PROPERTY readonly_property (str) Read-only property documentation. READWRITE_PROPERTY readwrite_property (list of int) Read-write property documentation. In this example, notice that: Docstring of __init__ function is treated as a class-level docstring. Type annotation using typing package ( List and Tuple in this case) is directly rendered. This behavior may be changed to more readable style in the future version . Bound method ( message in this case) has a METHOD prefix instead of a FUNCTION prefix. Type detection from type annotation for property has not been supported. Read-only property and read-write property are automatically determined. Data Class Code 4 example.ExampleDataClass @dataclass class ExampleDataClass: """A dataclass. Args: x: The first parameter Attributes: x: The first attribute """ x: int = 0 ![mkapi][example.ExampleDataClass] creates the API document for the ExampleDataClass class. DATACLASS example.ExampleDataClass (x=0) A dataclass. Parameters x (int) — The first parameter Attributes x — The first attribute In this example, notice that: DATACLASS prefix instead of CLASS . TODO: Attributes type annotation. TODO: Default value detection. Module You can also get a whole module API documentation. ![mkapi][example] creates the API document for the entire example module. MODULE example CLASS ExampleClass (x, y) A normal class. Parameters x (List[int]) — The first parameter. y (Tuple[str, int]) — The second parameter. Attributes z (str) — The first attribute. Raises ValueError — If the length of x is equal to 0. METHOD message (n) A bound method. Parameters n (int) — Repeatation Returns (str) A message READONLY_PROPERTY readonly_property (str) Read-only property documentation. READWRITE_PROPERTY readwrite_property (list of int) Read-write property documentation. DATACLASS ExampleDataClass (x=0) A dataclass. Parameters x (int) — The first parameter Attributes x — The first attribute FUNCTION add (x, y) Returns x + y x + y . Parameters x (int) — The first parameter. y (int) — The second parameter. Returns (int) Added value. Examples >>> add(1, 2) 3 Note You can use the admonition extension of MkDocs Note But you should use Note section instead for consistency. GENERATOR gen (n) Yields a numbered string. Parameters n (int) — The length of iteration. Yields (str) A numbered string
docs.title: Examples

docs.text: Let's start realistic examples. Here, sample Python source scripts are stored under the examples directory relative to mkdocs.yml , so you should configure mkdocs.yml like below. In addition, we add two extensions and extra javascript for demonstration. plugins: - search - mkapi: src_dirs: [examples] markdown_extensions: - admonition - pymdownx.arithmatex extra_javascript: - https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/mathjax/2.7.0/MathJax.js?config=TeX-MML-AM_CHTML
docs.title: Examples

docs.text: A Python module example.py defines a simple function add . Code 1 example.add def add(x: int, y: int) -> int: """Returns $x + y$. Args: x: The first parameter. y: The second parameter. Returns: Added value. Examples: >>> add(1, 2) 3 !!! note You can use the [admonition extension of MkDocs](https://squidfunk.github.io/mkdocs-material/extensions/admonition/) Note: But you should use `Note` section instead for consistency. """ return x + y Then, you can write an entry to generate API for the function anywhere in your Markdown source: ![mkapi][example.add] MkApi generates the API document for the add function. FUNCTION example.add (x, y) Returns x + y x + y . Parameters x (int) — The first parameter. y (int) — The second parameter. Returns (int) Added value. Examples >>> add(1, 2) 3 Note You can use the admonition extension of MkDocs Note But you should use Note section instead for consistency. Note In the above example, green dashed border is just to show the region of documentation generated by MkApi for convenience. In this simple example, you can see MkApi's features. Auto detection of the type of add (FUNCTION prefix). Type annotation and docstring update for both Parameters and Returns sections. External hyperlink. Use of MkDocs extensions: MathJax rendering and admonition.
docs.title: Function

docs.text: example.py alse defines a simple generator gen . Code 2 example.gen def gen(n) -> Iterator[str]: """Yields a numbered string. Args: n (int): The length of iteration. Yields: A numbered string """ for x in range(n): yield f"a{x}" Then, ![mkapi][example.gen] creates the API document for the gen generator. GENERATOR example.gen (n) Yields a numbered string. Parameters n (int) — The length of iteration. Yields (str) A numbered string Here, the parameter n has no type annotation but you can specify it in the Args section directly.
docs.title: Generator

docs.text: example.py alse defines a simple class ExampleClass . Code 3 example.ExampleClass class ExampleClass: def __init__(self, x: List[int], y: Tuple[str, int]): """A normal class. Args: x: The first parameter. y: The second parameter. Attributes: z (str): The first attribute. Raises: ValueError: If the length of `x` is equal to 0. """ if len(x) == 0: raise ValueError() self.z = "abc" def message(self, n: int) -> str: """A bound method. Args: n: Repeatation Returns: A message """ return self.z * n @property def readonly_property(self): """str: Read-only property documentation.""" return "readonly_property" @property def readwrite_property(self): """list of int: Read-write property documentation.""" return [1, 2, 3] @readwrite_property.setter def readwrite_property(self, value): pass As usual, ![mkapi][example.ExampleClass] creates the API document for the ExampleClass class. CLASS example.ExampleClass (x, y) A normal class. Parameters x (List[int]) — The first parameter. y (Tuple[str, int]) — The second parameter. Attributes z (str) — The first attribute. Raises ValueError — If the length of x is equal to 0. METHOD message (n) A bound method. Parameters n (int) — Repeatation Returns (str) A message READONLY_PROPERTY readonly_property (str) Read-only property documentation. READWRITE_PROPERTY readwrite_property (list of int) Read-write property documentation. In this example, notice that: Docstring of __init__ function is treated as a class-level docstring. Type annotation using typing package ( List and Tuple in this case) is directly rendered. This behavior may be changed to more readable style in the future version . Bound method ( message in this case) has a METHOD prefix instead of a FUNCTION prefix. Type detection from type annotation for property has not been supported. Read-only property and read-write property are automatically determined.
docs.title: Class

docs.text: Code 4 example.ExampleDataClass @dataclass class ExampleDataClass: """A dataclass. Args: x: The first parameter Attributes: x: The first attribute """ x: int = 0 ![mkapi][example.ExampleDataClass] creates the API document for the ExampleDataClass class. DATACLASS example.ExampleDataClass (x=0) A dataclass. Parameters x (int) — The first parameter Attributes x — The first attribute In this example, notice that: DATACLASS prefix instead of CLASS . TODO: Attributes type annotation. TODO: Default value detection.
docs.title: Data Class

docs.text: You can also get a whole module API documentation. ![mkapi][example] creates the API document for the entire example module. MODULE example CLASS ExampleClass (x, y) A normal class. Parameters x (List[int]) — The first parameter. y (Tuple[str, int]) — The second parameter. Attributes z (str) — The first attribute. Raises ValueError — If the length of x is equal to 0. METHOD message (n) A bound method. Parameters n (int) — Repeatation Returns (str) A message READONLY_PROPERTY readonly_property (str) Read-only property documentation. READWRITE_PROPERTY readwrite_property (list of int) Read-write property documentation. DATACLASS ExampleDataClass (x=0) A dataclass. Parameters x (int) — The first parameter Attributes x — The first attribute FUNCTION add (x, y) Returns x + y x + y . Parameters x (int) — The first parameter. y (int) — The second parameter. Returns (int) Added value. Examples >>> add(1, 2) 3 Note You can use the admonition extension of MkDocs Note But you should use Note section instead for consistency. GENERATOR gen (n) Yields a numbered string. Parameters n (int) — The length of iteration. Yields (str) A numbered string
